node.text:
Feel like you need some space? No need to planet out. Just watch this week’s Science Friday video! 

To celebrate our recent full certification as an International Dark Sky Park from the International Dark Sky Association @idadarksky, we went to talk to Glacier’s lead astronomy educator and east side interpreter, Lee Rademaker. 

Lee has been instrumental in bringing astronomy programming to park visitors, both in-person and online. We went over to the Dusty Star Observatory in St. Mary to learn about how the observatory works, why dark skies are important, and how we can stay connected to Glacier’s night skies from near and far. 

#ScienceFriday #ParkScience #Astronomy #Space #Telescope #NightSkies #DarkSkies

node.text:
Mountains are memorable, but chances are good that if you’ve visited Glacier, you’ve enjoyed some of the gorgeous grasslands on the park’s east side. You may have stopped at one to photograph wildflowers or watch a grizzly bear. A good example is in St. Mary, which you can view on this webcam. 

Prior to the establishment of the park, Native Americans followed bison across these grasslands, using traditional ecological knowledge to maintain a highly diverse and intact biome. Over the past century, the park’s grasslands have been impacted by settlement, livestock grazing, park and concessioner development, noxious weed invasion, and change in fire regimes. 

In 1999, park ecologists established 155 permanent vegetation monitoring plots in 99 different meadows. 

For this week’s Science Friday, we had the chance to go out with the botany crew. They’re spending the summer surveying those plots established 20 years ago to evaluate how the vegetation has changed. What changes do you think you might see? 

#sciencefriday #glaciernationalpark #parkscience #botany #wildflowers #ecology #climatechange

node.title: Science Friday - The Grasslands, They Are A-Changin'

node.text:
This video will help you prepare for using the recreation.gov mobile site to purchase a Going-to-the-Sun Road ticket. Tickets are limited and can sell out before you get one even if you are prepared, but knowing how to use the site puts you in the best position to successfully acquire one.

To learn more about ticketed entry visit our website, https://www.nps.gov/glac/planyourvisit/gtsrticketedentry.htm.

node.title: How To Get a $2 Going-to-the-Sun Road

node.text:
Glacier National Park is classified as a Class 1 airshed under the Clean Air Act. This designation affords the highest level of air quality protection provided under the Act. 

Fresh air, dramatic views, and pristine water are some of the qualities that draw visitors to Glacier from all over the world. Air quality in the park affects obvious things, like visibility. It also has less obvious impacts - on water quality, forest composition and ecosystem function. 

Glacier has had a permanent air quality monitoring site since 1980. The site includes devices and networks that measure different components of the atmosphere. 

Join us for this Science Friday, as the park's Physical Scientist shows us around the site and explains how we measure air quality in Glacier! 

#ScienceFriday #ScienceInParks #GlacierNationalPark #ParkScience #AirQuality

node.title: Science Friday- What's in the Air?

node.text:
You probably expect that Glacier protects things like bears and rivers. Did you know, though, that the park also protects and preserves over 700 historic structures?

Welcome back to Season Two of Science Fridays with Ranger Melissa! We are so excited to continue exploring, learning, and discovering science and research in the park with you! 
This week, we learn about historic buildings in Glacier from the park's historical architect, Kim Hyatt.

node.title: Science Friday - Historic Buildings of Glacier

node.text:
Have you missed us? Science Friday with Ranger Melissa is back with a great final Science Friday video for you! This week, Melissa goes out with John Waller, the park’s bear biologist, to explore the trail for signs of bears, discover differences between bears in Glacier and elsewhere, and learn about how bears live at different times of year. 

#ParkScience #ScienceFriday #Bears #Hibernation #GlacierNationalPark #WildlifeBiology #ScienceInParks

node.title: Science Friday - Glacier's Bears with John Waller

node.text: This week, we are bringing you a VERY special Science Friday. Ranger Melissa travels to an active archaeological site on the east side of the park to meet with archaeologist Brent Rowley. A river has been eroding away the bank, revealing some incredible things about the history of this place. Watch more to find out what they discover! #sciencefriday #parkscience #archaeology #scienceinparks #glaciernationalpark

node.title: Science Friday - Archaeological discovery with Brent Rowley

node.text:
Glacier National Park is seeking the public’s help in locating Jennifer (Jenn) Coleman.

She is believed to have been hiking around Logan Pass on 8/30 or 8/31. Coleman is 5’6” with blond, shoulder length hair and blue eyes. She was most likely hiking in an outfit like the one pictured (left). 

If you saw Jenn Coleman in Glacier National Park, please call the Glacier National Park tip line at 406-888-7077.

node.accessibility_caption: Two buildings sit on the shore of a lake with mountains in the distance.

node.text:
Of all the historic chalets built by the Great Northern Railway in Glacier National Park, the Gunsight Chalets were probably the most short-lived. Built around 1911 on the shores of Gunsight Lake, by approximately 1916 they were gone.

The chalets offered overnight accommodations to those traveling between Sperry Chalet and Going-to-the-Sun Chalets via the Gunsight Pass Trail. They consisted of a two-story dormitory and a kitchen/dining building. One winter, a grizzly bear significantly damaged one of the buildings. Repairs were made the following summer, but disaster struck again when the chalets were the victim of an avalanche in early 1916. This time, they weren’t rebuilt.

In "Glacier National Park: Its Trails and Treasures," authors Mathilde Edith Holtz and Katharine Isabel Bemis wrote about the chalets in glowing terms:

“A more quiet and secluded spot one cannot find in the Park. A great peace prevails. No sounds rise out of the depths and across the chasms, but the air seems full of melody—that illusion peculiar to vast solitudes. Nowhere in the Park did we feel so far away from the outside world or the madding crowd.”

Unfortunately, by the time this book was published in 1917, the chalets had already been destroyed. 

This photo was taken by R.E. Marble ca. 1914. #ThrowbackThursday #tbt

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on September 01, 2021. May be an image of one or more people and nature.

node.text:
While hiking, be sure to remember Leave No Trace Principle #2: Travel on Durable Surfaces!

Glacier National Park has hundreds of miles of trails to explore that will take you everywhere you need to go. In some highly sensitive areas, there are boardwalks which are especially important to stay on to avoid damaging fragile vegetation. It’s also important to make sure you aren’t walking on the edge of the trail. Some of Glacier's busiest trails have been widened more than 10 feet by spread out hikers!

Do you have a favorite trail in the park?

Image description: Three hikers on a trail facing large mountains in the distance.

node.accessibility_caption: Sun rays shine down through clouds and rain onto a hill in the foreground, with mountain peaks beyond.

node.text:
Happy last day of August! We always look forward to the fall colors and cooler temperatures of autumn, but we never know exactly what the weather will bring… Will it be warm and dry, cold and wet, an early snow, or a bit of everything? 

The safest bet is to be prepared for it all! If you’re planning a fall visit, be sure to check the weather ahead of time. Days are shorter, and nights are cooler. Bring plenty of warm, dry layers, especially when hiking. And stay alert for wildlife—especially bears—getting ready for winter!

What is your favorite part of fall?

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on August 30, 2021. May be an image of bird, nature and body of water.

node.text:
Rivers, lakes, and bogs make up a small percentage of Glacier’s land cover, yet they account for much of the park’s diversity. A tremendous number of birds, large and small, find a home in the park’s wetlands. The common loon (Gavia immer) population in the park is one of the most important in Montana. Approximately 20% of Montana’s nesting loons are in Glacier. They are listed as a Species of Special Concern in Montana because of their limited range, small population, sensitivity to human disturbance, and loss of breeding habitat outside of the park. 

For this reason, the Crown of the Continent Research Learning Center organizes citizen science volunteers to conduct annual loon surveys. Volunteers visit 45 priority lakes in the park two times each summer to survey for the presence of loons, breeding pairs, and any successful nesting. In 2020, park biologists and volunteers found 12 single adults and 23 pairs with a total of 10 chicks!

Image description: A loon in a lake with snowy mountains behind it.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on August 29, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing and outdoors.

node.text:
Want to know more about mountain goats, bears, or wolverines? How about glaciers, fire, or huckleberries? 

Join us for ranger-led programs each afternoon through Labor Day at the Apgar Nature Center in Apgar Village. Specific topics vary from day to day, but a 30-minute talk entitled Amazing Animals is scheduled at 1:30 pm every day, followed by a Ranger’s Choice talk at 3:00 pm. Additionally, wildlife safety talks take place every morning at 10:30 am, and guided hikes are offered on a limited basis throughout the park. 

Planning to be in the park late? Check out the wide array of evening programs offered at the Apgar, Fish Creek, Many Glacier, Rising Sun, and Two Medicine Campgrounds. All park visitors are welcome. 

Details about all of these ranger-led activities can be found at the Apgar, Logan Pass, and St. Mary Visitor Centers and in bulletin cases throughout the park. More information about how to prepare for a ranger-led program can be found on the park website. 

Image: a park ranger presenting to an audience in the forest.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Glacier National Park on August 28, 2021. May be an image of road, tree and nature.

node.text:
What’s your favorite time of year to visit Glacier National Park? 

Daily temperatures are starting to get cooler, and snow has already fallen in the higher elevations! Usually, as September progresses, visitation numbers trend downward. For this reason, many of the park’s services and nearby businesses will start implementing shorter hours or close for the season at some point during the coming month. 

One important service that will shut down soon is the park’s Ticket-to-Ride shuttle system. Labor Day (September 6) is the last day park shuttles will be running. After this, visitors wishing to see Going-to-the-Sun Road must drive their own vehicles or arrange for private transportation. 

As snow becomes more frequent at high elevations and temperatures fluctuate throughout the day, the condition of the road can worsen very rapidly. Unsafe driving conditions on Going-to-the-Sun Road may prompt park staff to close a portion of it temporarily until it becomes safe to drive again. 

Even though services and high-elevation access are more limited during the shoulder season, you may prefer to visit the park at this time, as there tend to be fewer crowds, and precipitation and autumn foliage begin to turn mountainsides to stunning green-gold-white mosaics. Keep in mind that the weather can change dramatically though, so please be flexible with your plans, and pack clothing and gear for the whole range of possible conditions, from heat to freezing cold and from full sun to rain, sleet, and snow. 

Image: a park shuttle drives a mountainous road with flowers in the foreground.

node.accessibility_caption: A man sits on a horse next to a lake. A glacier hugs the side of a mountain wall behind him.

node.text:
Sometimes known as the “Poet of the Rockies,” Jim Whilt (1878-1967) was a colorful person in Glacier’s history. He spent over 30 years in the park, working as a trapper, guide, and camptender.

As a guide for horseback trips, Whilt took part in the tradition of telling tall tales and spinning yarns about the park to entertain the “dudes” under his charge. He gathered some of his musings (many of which we might call “dad jokes” today) into a volume called “Giggles from Glacier Guides,” published in 1935. Here are some excerpts from that work:

“In the spring my work starts as the snows are leaving, having to set out wild flowers over five miles of trails to Grinnell Glacier; various waterfalls have to be turned on and several rock gardens have to be planted. Some plants have to be put in where it is impossible to climb. For this I have two trained monkeys.”

“Speaking of sheep, we have the usual bighorn. Some old rams have horns so large they are unable to carry them naturally. They have conceived the idea of putting two small wheels under their chins so as to support the weight of their horns. In winter they substitute runners in place of the wheels. We have two kinds of sheep, the bighorn that I have just told you about, and the other is called the iron sheep. Every spring we have to round up the latter and shear them, for it is the iron sheep that furnishes the steel wool.”

In a 1938 issue of the park’s “Glacial Drift” naturalist newsletter, ranger H.E. Bailey wrote this about Whilt:

“...One of the best known guides working for the Saddle Horse Company is Jim Whilt, who was assigned the trip to Grinnell Glacier five years ago. Jim claims this was done because it would be no loss to the company if he fell into a crevasse ‘whereas if another guide met the same fate, it would be a severe loss.’ [...] He advises those who have never ridden a horse before to inform him of the fact in advance so that he can pick out a horse that has never been ridden, and the two can learn together.”

This photo, taken by John Kabel in the early 1940s, shows Whilt on horseback next to Josephine Lake with Grinnell Glacier in the background. #ThrowbackThursday

node.text:
What’s your favorite bighorn sheep sighting?

Bighorn sheep–famous for their large, curly horns–are a common sight in the high elevation areas of Glacier National Park. Sheep live in sex-segregated herds—a group will be either all rams, or a mix of ewes and kids. Sheep of both sexes have horns, although the larger, curlier horns belong to the males. Unlike an antler, a sheep horn is never shed; it continues to grow throughout a sheep’s life. These horns can weigh as much as 30 pounds!

As you can see in this video, the large horns of the male sheep are used for the species’ notorious ramming behavior. To settle dominance status within the herd, rams will repeatedly run and clash their horns together. This behavior is usually seen just before the fall rut.

node.accessibility_caption: A colorful duck stands on a rock amidst rushing water and flaps its wings.

node.text:
How do you LNT (leave no trace) while enjoying Glacier’s creeks and rivers?

These are great places to explore, but they’re also important habitats for birds, fish, insects, and lots of other plants and animals that call the park home. 

It may seem fun to stack rocks or build dams along the creeks, but moving rocks around can disturb animals that live under rocks or lay their eggs there. Creating dams can make it hard for harlequin ducks (seen here) and their chicks, along with many species of fish, to move up and down the creek. They also can slow water flow, warming up the water and stressing temperature-sensitive animals. 

Thank you for leaving rocks where they are and helping keep our waterways wild!

node.accessibility_caption: A colorful duck stands on a rock amidst rushing water and flaps its wings.
A close-up image of a stone fly perching on the side of a red-orange rock next to a creek.
An underwater image of several cutthroat trout.
Two alpine lakes beneath mountains in a forested valley.

node.text:
Do you like swimming? 

Glacier's lakes, fed by snowmelt and glacial runoff, aren't for the faint of heart. In the summer—if you stand near the water's edge long enough—you'll hear a chorus of yelps and startled shouts from the brave souls wading in. 

But recently, many lakes here have been... warm?

Mid-August is when average water temperatures tend to peak in Glacier. Summer temperatures rise as snowmelt dwindles, driving water temperatures to warm throughout the summer. But while this warm(er) water can be pleasant for us, it can be hazardous to wildlife. 

Native fish, like the Bull Trout, require cold water habitat because cold water holds more oxygen. The warmer the water, the less oxygen is available, and the more stressed fish can become. Outside Glacier, it's gotten warm enough that Montana Fish, Wildlife & Parks has closed different rivers to anglers during the hottest times of the day—the added stress of fishing could kill fish.

This past week has brought cooler weather to Glacier, and water temperatures are likely to begin their steady decline to winter weather. Whether warm or cold, Glacier's water reminds us that every little change can have a large ripple effect.

Image: Alpine lakes beneath mountains in a forested valley.

node.text:
Glacier National Park is a hiker’s paradise! With over 700 miles of hiking trails to choose from, there’s something for everyone. What’s your favorite type of landscape to explore on hikes? Lush, temperate forests on the west side of the park? Aspen parklands and craggy cliffs on the east? Scenic lakes, streams, and waterfalls? Or perhaps high alpine meadows and talus slopes at the crest of the mountains? 

When planning your next hiking adventure here, check out our internet resources. Day hike information for each area can be found on the park’s website. Keep in mind that the distances specified are one-way, so the entire length of your out-and-back hike will be twice the mileage listed. 

Please be safe while you explore Glacier’s many day hikes. Carry food, water, bear spray, rain gear, extra layers, and a first aid kit. Several short videos on our website can help you learn more about staying safe while hiking.

Happy trails!
